revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=July 2016}} {{Infobox person | image = KeenenIvoryWayansHWOFMay2013.jpg | caption = Wayans in 2013 | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1958|6|8}} | birth_place = [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]], United States | other_names = | occupation = Actor, comedian, filmmaker | years_active = 1979–2009; 2013–present | family = See [[Wayans Family]] | spouse = | website = | children = 5 | education = [[Tuskegee University]] | awards = 1990-Emmy Award '''[[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Variety, Music Or Comedy Series|Outstanding Variety, Music or Comedy Series]]'''
''[[In Living Color]]'' (as executive producer) }} '''Keenen Ivory Desuma Wayans, Sr.''' (born June 8, 1958) is an American actor, comedian, filmmaker, and a member of the [[Wayans family]] of entertainers. He first came to prominence as the host and the creator of the 1990–1994 [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] sketch comedy series ''[[In Living Color]]''. He has produced, directed and/or written a large number of films, starting with ''[[Hollywood Shuffle]]'', which he co-wrote, in 1987. A majority of these films have included him and one or more of his brothers and sisters in the cast. One of these films, ''[[Scary Movie]]'' (2000), which Wayans directed, was the highest-grossing movie ever directed by an African American until it was surpassed by [[Tim Story]]'s ''[[Fantastic Four (2005 film)|Fantastic Four]]'' in 2005. From 1997 to 1998, he hosted the talk show ''[[The Keenen Ivory Wayans Show]]''.{{cite news|title= Will 'Hip' Equal 'Hit'? |work= [[Los Angeles Times]]|date=August 3, 1997|url= http://articles.latimes.com/1997/aug/03/entertainment/ca-18836|accessdate=2011-11-06|first=Greg|last=Braxton}} Most recently, he was a judge for the eighth season of ''[[Last Comic Standing]]''. ==Life and career== Wayans was born in [[Harlem]], [[New York City]], son of Howell Stouten Wayans, a supermarket manager, and his wife Elvira Alethia (Green), a homemaker and social worker.Stated on ''[[Finding Your Roots]]'', January 19, 2016, PBS[https://www.pbs.org/weta/finding-your-roots/blog/keenen-ivory-wayans-interactive-family-tree/ PBS] His father was a devout [[Jehovah's Witness]].[http://www.filmreference.com/film/9/Keenen-Ivory-Wayans.html Keenen Ivory Wayans Biography (1958–)]{{cite news| url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,997920,00.html | work=Time | title=Marlon Wayans | first=Joel | last=Stein | date=September 11, 2000}}[http://www.themoviechicks.com/mid2004/mctladykillers.html The Movie Chicks – Interview – Marlon Wayans] The family later moved to Manhattan's [[Fulton Houses|Fulton]] housing projects.{{cite news |title= Is prime time ready for rudeness? Fox's new comedy 'In Living Color' will offend some, tickle others |work= The San Diego Union |date= April 13, 1990 |first= Robert P. |last= Laurence |url= http://infoweb.newsbank.com/iw-search/we/InfoWeb?p_product=AWNB&p_theme=aggregated5&p_action=doc&p_docid=1178BA5E348E4AB6&p_docnum=845&p_queryname=3 |page= E1 }}, where he primarily grew up. Wayans attended [[Tuskegee University]] on an engineering scholarship. He entertained his friends at college with made-up stories about life in New York.{{cite news |title= Laughing with 'Living Color' |work= USA Today |date= April 13, 1990 |first= Mike |last= Hughes |url= http://infoweb.newsbank.com/iw-search/we/InfoWeb?p_product=AWNB&p_theme=aggregated5&p_action=doc&p_docid=128129675C049B80&p_docnum=850&p_queryname=3 }} One semester before graduation, he dropped out of school to focus on comedy.{{cite news |title= Keenen Wayans gambles and wins on an offbeat 'Sucka' |work= The San Diego Union |date= February 16, 1989 |first= Mike |last= McIntyre |page= E3 |url= http://infoweb.newsbank.com/iw-search/we/InfoWeb?p_product=AWNB&p_theme=aggregated5&p_action=doc&p_docid=1178C747FA9CF8B5&p_docnum=78&p_queryname=3 }} During his first set performing at [[The Improv]] in New York, Wayans met [[Robert Townsend (actor)|Robert Townsend]], who helped him learn about the comedy business. Townsend and Wayans drove cross country to Los Angeles together when Wayans moved to Los Angeles in 1980. They didn't speak for a year afterwards. Wayans worked there as an actor. He had a regular role as a soldier on a television series named "[[For Love and Honor]]". Townsend wrote, directed, and starred in the movie ''[[Hollywood Shuffle]]''; Wayans was co-star and co-writer. The movie's success allowed him to raise the money to make ''[[I'm Gonna Git You Sucka]]''. [[Fox Broadcasting Company]] approached Wayans to offer him his own show.{{cite news |title= New Fox Show Pokes Fun at Black Stereotypes |publisher= Greensboro News & Record |location= Greensboro, North Carolina |work= Associated Press |page= B6 |date= April 12, 1990 |url= http://infoweb.newsbank.com/iw-search/we/InfoWeb?p_product=AWNB&p_theme=aggregated5&p_action=doc&p_docid=0EB191E9F73E3517&p_docnum=837&p_queryname=3 }} Wayans wanted to produce a variety show, similar to [[Saturday Night Live]], with a cast of people of color that took chances with its content. Fox gave Wayans a lot of freedom with the show, although Fox executives were a bit concerned about the show's content prior to its television debut. Wayans created, wrote, and starred in the show, called ''[[In Living Color]]'', an American [[sketch comedy]] television series that originally ran on the [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox Network]] from 1990 to 1994. ==''In Living Color''== ===Characters=== *Death Row Comic (''Prison Cable Access'') *Frenchie *Ice Man (''Homeboy Shopping Network'') *Tom Brothers (''The Brothers Brothers'') *Wes (''Wes & Les'') ===Impressions=== *[[Arsenio Hall]] *[[Billy Dee Williams]] *[[Don Cornelius]] *[[Jesse Jackson]] *[[Little Richard]] *[[Mike Tyson]] *[[Marsha Warfield]] *Milli ([[Rob Pilatus]]) of Milli Vanilli *[[Morgan Freeman]] (such as Hoke Colburn from ''Driving Miss Daisy'', Principal Joe Clark from ''Lean on Me'') *[[Rick James]] *[[Steve Harvey]] *[[Carl Weathers]] (as [[Apollo Creed]]) ==Filmography== {| class="wikitable" ! Year !! Title !! Jim Campbell |- | 1997 || ''[[Most Wanted (1997 film)|Most Wanted]]'' || Gunnery Sergeant James Dunn |- | 2000 || ''[[Scary Movie]]'' || Slave (Amistad II) |- | 2001 || ''[[My Wife and Kids]]'' || Ken |- | 2009 || ''[[Dance Flick]]'' || Mr. Stache |- | 2013 || ''[[Happily Divorced]]'' || Tony |- | 2014 || ''[[Last Comic Standing]]'' || Judge |- |} ===Writing/producing/directing credits=== *''[[Hollywood Shuffle]]'' (1987) (writer) *''[[Eddie Murphy Raw]]'' (1987) (writer and producer) *''[[I'm Gonna Git You Sucka]]'' (1988) (writer and director) *''[[In Living Color]]'' (1990–1992; 2013–) (executive producer, director and creator/writer) *''[[The Five Heartbeats]]'' (1991) (writer) *''[[A Low Down Dirty Shame]]'' (1994) (writer and director) *''[[Don't Be a Menace to South Central While Drinking Your Juice in the Hood]]'' (1996) (producer) *''[[The Keenen Ivory Wayans Show]]'' (1997) (executive producer) *''[[Most Wanted (1997 film)|Most Wanted]]'' (1997) (executive producer and writer) *''[[Scary Movie]]'' (2000) (actor and director) *''[[Scary Movie 2]]'' (2001) (director) *''[[White Chicks]]'' (2004) (producer, director) *''[[Little Man (2006 film)|Little Man]]'' (2006) (producer, writer, director) *''[[Dance Flick]]'' (2009) (producer, writer) *''The Boo Crew'' (2017) (creator, producer, writer) ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{IMDb
